text: On tap @ Rattle N Hum. This is a darker looking one deeper ruby looking in color with a nice big lasting and leaving small dots down the glass off-white head. Surprisingly mild aroma. Expected a big punchy nose, didnt get that. Is a subtle softly dark caramel sweet one. Traces of nuts and earth. Tastes really good. Not too sweet at all, but it has a lot of dark caramel raisin sweetness. Almost like burnt raisins from a bun. It has a mild sticky kinda oily texture in the mouth and its creamy prickling on the bubbles. Lots of red berries like cranberries and freeze dried raspberries. Lots of flavor, and thank god its not too sweet. Like it quite a lot. 17.06.2015
2 oz draft pour at SAVOR 2016s Saturday session. Clear golden amber with beige head. Aromas of caramel, toffee, booze. Tastes of caramel, toffee, booze, butterscotch. Medium body with a dry finish.

Draft at the brewery, served in a flight. Pours a clear amber with a small off-white head that settles into a ring. Notes of banana, caramel, dried fruits, and brown sugar. Some earthy, slightly odd notes from the EKG hops. Medium-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a sweet, astringent mouthfeel. Its okay.

Draught at Bear Republic. Clear amber liquid with medium white head. Aroma of caramel, raw sugar, raisins and dried fruit. Taste is light sweet and light bitter with notes of caramel, toffee and light grain. Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Decent.
Draft at source. Aroma is peaty, earthy, light smoke. Deep red color with small white head. Taste is caramel forward with very inviting hints of molasses and peat smoked malt. Really good.

Keg at the brewpub, Healdsburg, 04/02/16.
Rich chestnut brown with a decent beige covering. 
Nose is sweet malt, toffee, pear drop, fruit esters.
Taste comprises butterscotch, caramel, fruit rinds, biscuit.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close. 
Decent for style.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Draft at the brewpub. Pours clear gold with a creamy white head. Nice toffee and caramel in the nose, some fruits. Medium to heavy sweet flavor with lots of semi-dark fruits, creamy toffee, dates. Medium bodied with fine carbonation. Sugary finish with plenty of bready malts, more toffee, ripe fruits. Nice.

Sample on tap at the brewpub. Clear copper pour with thin creamy white head. Aroma is very fruity, sweet malty aromas, tons of caramel, rich pear like aromas. Taste is sweet, very rich, caramel, boozy fruits. Palate is med-full bodied with med carbonation. Decent.
Really good malty nose from dark brown pour. Taste malty and somewhat sweet with a nice alcohol warmth. Finish lingers of sweet caramel and some sweet malts as well.

Draught at Apex, Portland, as Bear Republic Heritage Wee Heavy, 8.1% ABVDark mahogany color. Heavy caramel aroma and flavor, robust body, fairly sweet, not much bitterness, some alcohol perception, and as often happens for these beers, lack of character.
Dark reddish brown in color... Aroma of caramel toffee... Flavor is dark fruits, nuts, light oak... Really good

Tap. Sweet aroma. No head. Malt, spice, floral and molasses notes. Long finish. Ok but a bit sweet. Probably could not have more than one. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a dark caramel color with white head. Malt, peat, earthy, fruit and caramel aroma and flavors. Medium body and mild carbonation. Fruit, peat and caramel finish.

On tap @ Bear Republic. Pours thin dark reddish brown with minimal head. Aroma is sweet oaky malt. Taste is similar, slightly boozy on the finish. Not my favorite style and I liked this. Plenty of malty flavor.

"a very smooth, medium bodied (especially for the higher abv), solid brew! its sweet, but not overly so, and the msokiness from the peet is pretty subtle, so that even my peet-hating wife enjoyed it. hints of dark malt and sweet fruitiness in the nose. classic flavor, minus a touch of smoke. good balance."

A bite of sourness. A nice drinkable, not too strong scotch. Still sour! Hint of molasses and loads of bourbon. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Tap, amber pour, off white head, nose is toffee, taste is caramel, sweet, lovely finish.
Draft - Toffee and toasted malts. Clear dark amber with a decent brown head. Caramel and whiskey notes with a long sweet finish. A little on the sweet but a nice Scottish.

On tap @ Bear Republic. Dark amber colored beer with an off-white head. Aromas of dark fruit (raisin and dates), caramel, and brown sugar. A touch of toasted nuts, toffee, and maybe some alcohol. Flavor is quite sweet and sugary. Tons of toffee, caramel, and dark fruit. A nice nuttiness. Light booze, some chocolate, and vanilla.

On tap at Bear Republic, pours a deep dark amber with a small beige head. Aroma is very sweet, with notes of raisins, caramel malts, and syrup. Flavour is very sweet, bringing out shitloads of raisins, followed by caramel malt. Very sweet, but somehow not cloying, at least not in this small quantity. Solid, but not the most complex for the style.
Tap at Bear Republic, Healdsburg. Colour is reddish brown with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Fruits, nuts, sweetness and malts.

Tap - pours dark brown with crimson highlights. Nice, full, thick lasting tan-white head. Nice malty smoke bread notes, hints of caramel-vanilla, definitely Scotch ale nose. Esters. Taste is biscuit, malted nuts, roast caramel. Medium to lighter bodied, fairly lively. Decent finish, with lingering nutty vanilla ester notes.

On tap at Eddies Roadhouse.  Pours a rather hazed brown with a thin white head.  Aromas of malt all over, sweet fruit and caramel.  Big and sticky sweet, full of malt and caramel, a bit of toffee and some dark stone fruit notes.  Warming esters and a touch of alcohol.  Warm and sweet.  A little sweeter than I usually like, but still fairly well balanced and smooth.

Pours red/dark orange, hazy, off-white rocky head, decent retention and lacing. Aroma is malt, whiskey, fresh oak, pretty mellow over all. Flavor is subdued but scotch ale-ish with lots of oak flavor. Caramel with a bit of whiskey, nuttiness, and vanilla. Low/medium CO2. Body is medium/heavy and pretty drinkable.

Nice light enough fruit punch flavor to add dimension to the malt character and the Scotch type mouthfeel (like a broth) and typical peaty in sweetness finish with perhaps a little burn in the froth. hummm all in one sentence.

Tap @ Shortys w andy james feng dubra. Dark brown, light tan head. Light chocolatey aroma with some sweet fruit. Similar taste, kind of has the consistency of chocolate milk with a lingering sweetness in the aftertaste. Palate is a tad watery for me but still tasty.

Draft at The Pour House in Westmont, NJ. 

Pours a dark chocolate brown color with faint mahogany edges and a frothy one finger beige head.  Good retention slowly fading into a lasting ring.  Streaks and spots of soapy lacing left behind. 

Slightly smokey aroma with lots of peppery spice and roasted malt.  Hints of bread, clove and pepper followed by toast, chocolate and caramel.  

Medium bodied with a decent balance of  dark malt, zesty spice and dark fruit.   Spice is more prominent than expected with hints lots of peppery clove.  This is followed by hints of eye, toffee and caramel as well as some grape and dark berries.

Draught. Hazy with no head or lace.  Aroma of orchard fruit esters and malt.  No noticeable hops except a little spiciness on the back. Slick thick n oily with a little metallic aftertaste. Nice for a change but not an awesome example.

Serving: Draft at Roasthouse Pub.  It pours brown with small head.  The nose has some earth but is mostly fruity.  The flavor is sweet with notes of cherry, earth, and some booze.  Medium bodied with average carbonation and a fruity finish.  It struck me as a darker, fruity, slightly boozy amber. Not bad, not great.  Take it or leave it.

Hazy copper pour with thin head.
Big malty nose, hints of maple syrup Semisweet overall.
Light body. Pleasant to drink but not mind blowing.
On tap at te Roasthouse early this week.  Lighht Brown color, with no head or lacing, Grapes and port and caramel with some candy sweetness
Draft at Rattle with Andrew. Pours a hazy ruby red body with no head or lacing. Aroma is fruits and light cherry. Mouthfeel is light with notes of cherry, fruit malts and light hops.
Draught Pours clear brown with little tan head. Aromas are light but sweet and malty. Tastes are light sweetness and some maple. Body is thin for the style.
Pours brown with a brown sugar taste but not overly sweet.  Goes down smooth and is light on the palate to not to overpower a lighter dish.

On tap at Beer Republic during SF Beer Week, what a week! Pours murky dark brown with thin tan head. The aroma offers up sweet dark fruity esters like prunes, figs and dates as well as some roasted malts and chocolate malts. The taste begins with a sweet dark fruity ester onslaught coming from all direction via prunes, raisins and figs and then picking up a modest amount of dark roasted malts, chocolate malts and a mild yet pleasing earthiness. It lingers with some chocolate and roasted malts into the finish. Pretty right on for the style.
On tap at Lyons Fork. Pours a dark brown with sticky lacing. Sweet, peaty aroma.  Smooth malt profile in the flavor. Not overly sweet. Light bodied and delicious.

Half pint @ Chucks. Not sure what the deal is but I cant seem to smell much of anything. That leaves a saccharine sweet malt base that Im glad I only got half a pint. Maybe Im done with scotch ales?

Tap at Mahaffeys.  Pours clear dark brown with a medium, fizzy light tan head, medium retention with good lacing.  Aroma is cookie and caramel, nutty malt with dates and earthy hops.  Flavor is malt dominant with fruity esters and light hops and bitterness with a sweet finish.  Full body, medium warmth and carbonation.
Amber pour, off white head.  Malty, peaty aroma.  Flavor is sweet up front, peat, sweet brown sugar notes and very light hops on the finish.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2012 For a brewery that most of us associate with West Coast hoppy ales, Bear Republic brews an authentic Scotch Ale.  Thick beige head, mahogany body, light hops, caramel, peat and earthiness.  Very drinkable considering the higher alcohol content.  Perfect mild winter ale.

Tap. Pours deep, dark brown with medium, creamy beige thick head; good retention and lacing. Aroma is heavy dark fruit, licorice, sweet malt, and light booze. Flavor is malt forward, faint hops, and heavy esters; fruity finish. Medium body, low carbonation, and high warmth.

Well now there is a fucking pta meeting at the bar. Dogs are still barking and there are even more fucking babies wandering;rolling around. Apparently the woman next to me daughter is 22 and high maintainenance... she needs the dick probably. Wow I need to leave. Shut up old ass lady. Your voice hurts my ears and head. A dude with a fanny pack is rating beer. This is the hobby I chose? Fucccckkkkk meeeeeee.... anyways... beer smells like malt, toast brown bread apple. Fuck apparently these kids are twins... congratufuckinglations. Beer is brown. Beer has thin head. Brown bread caramel apple a little roast. Smooth dry.  Its a scotch. Nothing special. Not bad. Fuck im up out this bitch. Im going tanning. Boom.

Aroma of sweet malts, figs, and some spice notes (cinnamon).  Pours brown with a medium creamy foam.  Tastes of darks fruits (dates-figs) with slight banana and sweet chocolate.  Wonderfully smooth and complex.  Definitely one of my favorite WeeHeavys.

Hanging with JoeT at the brewery on Aug 9, 2011 for my birthday.  I was more focused on the company than the notes, but thesell do until I get back there this summer and do it right.  Brown red pour.  Lotsa raisin and dark sweet.  Very nice.  (As my afternoon wore on, the scores got higher.  Was it the beers, or the beers?).
Dark ruby body with a light tan head. Semi sweet scent of caramel. Tastes drier than expected, and not as full. Caramel and roast are the primary elements.

This was tasted at the Capital Ale House on my birthday with my daughter.  The dark ale with small head was sweet and had a soft carbonation.  The smooth finish with no aftertaste was goood but could use  more hops to add a lttle bitterness.  Some toffe and brwon suger taste.
Draught at Churchkey. Cloudy brown pour. Nose and flavor are marked by toffee, caramel, light vinous notes, and black cherry dark fruit notes, though nothing impressive. Fine, but unimpressive.

Clear brown pour with garnet tints and no head. Acetone nail polish remover in the nose with lots of toffee malt gives way to caramel, molasses, and hints of smoke. Medium to thick palate with low carbonation, making for a syrupy sweet finish.

Served on draft at Beer Run. Pours a dark brown color with a medium creamy tan head. Decent head retention. Aroma of toffee, caramel, berries and faint hops. The taste is toffee, earth, anise, berries and faint hops. Medium bodied, low carbonation and slight warmth. Decent.

Growler fill from Whole Foods Short Pump.  Pours a clear dark brown with a lovely tan head, nice.  Aroma is light, but caramel shows through.  Flavor is fairly rich caramel, with some faint notes of dark fruit.  But mostly just a malt experience, with some balancing bitterness on the finish.  Surprisingly medium bodied as opposed to coming across as huge or syrupy.  Nicely done brew.

Draught. Pours a clear dark reddish brown with no head. Smells of caramel malts and brown sugar. Tastes of a heavy sweetness, with a mellow bitterness to soften the blow. Some wooden notes, but mostly caramel. Medium bodied. Texture is oily. Finish is wet.

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2012 Tap.  Pours a deep brown with a nice head that lingers.  The flavor is malty with a nice roasted flavor and very smooth.  Mild aftertaste.  Excellent overall. Re-classified to a Scottish ale?
solid scotch ale, very strong and bitter, decent amount of hops, had a touch of fruitiness as well.  Very complex beer, worth trying if you see it.  Had it on tap, abv well hidden.

B republic heritage... @ pap on tap 12/14/10
Buttery malt,some florals, cola and some choco notes. unnoticed hop presence. oily, sweet and snooze-worthy. 

dark brownish/ amber tints with no head after arrival. no flaws but meh. 5/4/5/3/13
From n.california trip notes:  on tap at brewery as part of a sampler.  big sweet malt aroma.  caramel, dries out in finish.  light chocolate. ok. 6.4

This is for the malt lovers out there. It has a very dark appearance with almost no head. The aroma is dark fruits, molasses, caramel, a touch of earth. The flavor has all the same with a nice hearty feel to it. Made for the cold wet days of fall and winter.

Draft in a pint glass - pours brown with light head. Aroma is smoky, caramel and candy. Taste is sweet. Aftertaste is smoky. RemInds me of a mild doppelbock. Tasty but I doubt there is little repeat value for this beer.
UPDATED: AUG 1, 2011 Molasses caramelly nose, Scotch ale taste without any hop taste.  Your standard, gateway safe scotch ale. Takes no risks, makes no mistakes.
On tap at Zenos. Dark brown with minimal head. Aroma is caramel. Flavor is caramel and flat soda. Not very good.
Draught from Blind Tiger. Poured a dark brownish black, the malt is strong in this one. I liked her.

Pours a dark reddish brown color with a thin white head.  Aroma of caramel, dark fruit, and some roasted malt.  Flavor is quite sweet with lots of caramel and dark fruit.  Just a touch of roasted malt.  Very nice beer!
Tap. Rating #90. Dark red/brown with a light tan head. Light sweetness in the nose. Flavor was dark fruit sweetness, a little dry with a touch of roast. Not bad. (1537)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text:
Sampled on tap at 1702; March 2011
This beer arrives with a tan colored head that sits on top of a dark, brown-amber colored beer.  A big caramel character is noticeable in the nose up front and this is backed by aromas of dark fruit, toasty malt touches and just a hearty, appetizing character that is quite nice, though definitely malt focused.

My first sip is sweet, with rich caramel notes that accentuate fruit notes of raisins and a big prune like flavor.  Softer toasted whole grain notes support the sweeter / fruitier notes from up front.  This has a nice, chewy body that is quite hefty for a beer of this strength.  There is a touch of roasted malt in the finish that helps add a light bitterness to go along with the touch of bitterness from the soft hop contribution.  This is actually quite nice; I really ike the malt character and the noticeable fruit component is nice, even if a bit divergent from a traditional American interpretation of a Scotch Ale.

On tap at 1702 in Tucson 
Appearance: Clear dark mahogany with a small beige head and some lacing 
Aroma: Sweet malts and caramel 
Taste: Sweet malts and caramel 
OK, nothing that really stood out
On tap @ 1702 - Pours a clear light brown color with a faint off white head.  Faint lacing.  Aroma and flavor is toasted caramel malt and light esters.  Medium body.  Nothing special, but drinkable.

Deep brown, almost indistinguishable from a stout (which I had in a glass next to it) except when held up to the light, at which time its nice brown, bright character became apparent.  Flavor/Aroma is slight roast, slight smoke (perhaps imagined) and slight to moderate delicious caramel sweetness.  I drank this one fast (especially near the end).  A lovely scotch ale!
Draft at 4th ave pub. Pours a dark brown no head. Smells of malt, toffee and carmel. Tastes the same. Nothing different going on here. Pretty decent scotch ale
On tap at Neighborhood in San Diego.  Pours a dark brownish red with tan head.  Smells of peat and roasted maltiness.  Taste is sweet, toffee, smokiness.
On tap at The Bronx Ale House.  A good scotch ale, with flavors of herbs and caramel.  A fine, malty brew.
Very sweet honey aroma.  Cider-brown in appearance. A very sweet bready tasting beer.
(On tap at Papago). Pours ruby/dark mahogany with a thin khaki head.  Taste is malty sweet. Medium bodied with an oily, slick texture. A little prickly on the tongue.  Smooth finish.  Solid brew.

Pours a lightist brown with a bit of crimson in there. Nice head and plenty of legs as it went down. Nice malt presence, with a few backing hops. Lots of dark fruits and a bit of red fruit. The taste is quite sweet and a bit cloying, but not overly so. Mouthfeel is medium and drinkability is very nice. This was one of my wifes favorites of the California leg of our trip.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 02-16-2010

(Old BA rate - tap)
Deep rich brown with coppery hints; thin tan head. Prune-like sweetness; whiff of smokiness; dark fruits in the aroma. Much less fruity than in the aroma; dry peat; earthy; roasted; decent. Thicker to medium MF; virtually still in terms of carbonation. Not bad, but got to be a little tougher as I went through the sample. Overall, different enough in the style that was semi-interesting
Tap @ Hamiltons.  Pours a mostly clear reddish amber with a small beige head.  Nice nose of roasted malts, faint grassy hops and a touch of toffee and caramel.

16oz glass at Deep Ellum.  Pours a translucent, mahogany brown with a creamy off white head.  Aroma has pale malts, some light chocolate powder, light brown sugar, sweet.  Flavor is real weak, watered down chocolate, light toasted malts, loads of crystal malt flavor.  Finish is weak and water.  A scotch ale?  No way.  This is a bad scotch ale.  This wouldnt even be a good brown ale.

Reviewed 1/30/2010 (Draft @ Flying Saucer, Houston, TX):

Pours a very dark yellowish red brown color body, opaque.  Small whitish head, somewhat lasting.  Hoppy malty sweet aroma, syrupy.  Fruity like strawberries, seeded fruit. Sweet syrupy taste, some hoppiness, citrus.  Some roastedness. Not my thing.  Dark brown sugar like taste.

Sample at Barleys Smokehouse. Pours a clear brown with a medium tan head. Banana aroma with roast and sugar. Sweet caramel flavor with a hint of banana before a boozy finish. Didnt know the style going in and was very surprised to see Scotch ale what with the banana character and all. Would have guessed a Belgian brown or a very tame quad given the color and sweetness. Odd for a Scotch, but not bad.
Pours with a dark brown body topped by a thin head with some lacing. Its sweet and malty with notes of dark fruit and a very light peaty, roast note.  Full bodied and smooth.

Tap at Petrol Station.Pours a thin, lifeless brown with a nose of slightly candied tea with a hint of copper.  Flavor starts out malty sweet but slowly fades into a sweet, hoppy goo.  Surprisingly carbonated for such a flat-looking beer.  Says "barrel aged" but there aint no barrel essence in here.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: On draft at Bear Republic Brewing (Healdsburg, CA): Pours out a rich, mahogany brown with amber highlights- here we go, this looks inviting. Nose of pale malts, brown sugar, and weak cocoa powder- maybe not. Minor toasty flavors amid a mix of mild chocolate. Starchy, grainy, on the verge of cloying, with a very thin malt base. Dry bitter finish. Drinkability: Commercial and forgettable. Pairing: Substantial desserts. Rebuy: No. #364 on 31032010, DG.

On tap at Downtown Johnnie Browns.   Nice red color.  Super malty, very sweet and a fair amount of heat.   Its 7.6%, but it feels like its 10%.   This was good, but I dont know that I would want more than one.
Very dark red. Big tan head. Strong, staunch malt aroma with brown sugar syrup. Sweet, malty flavor. Very sugary. Salty finish.
Draft at Gingerman in Austin. Nice and malty but not super exciting. Sweet malt, caramel, some roast.

(Draught)  Pours a hazy amber-brown body with small beige head.  Aroma of raisins, plum, toffee, and caramel.  Flavor of plum, raisins, chocolate, toasted rye, and caramel malt with a syrupy mouthfeel.  Quite sweet.
very dark ruby pour smell of malts fill your nose very little hop flavor malts through and though. fine example of a wee heavy
On tap at the Fort Worth Gingerman.  Dark red pour with a small brown head.  Aroma is sweet malt, raisins, and brown sugar.  Taste has tons of malt, sweet, a little dark fruit, and more brown sugar.

Tap at Gman. Slightly opaque ruby pour. Little head. Very immense malty sweet aroma. Sweet dark fruit and peet Irish moss. Heavy mouthfeel. Huge malt response with wet tea leaves. Quite mossy and earthy. Flavor of bitter cherries also come through. This is very nice.

I admire this beer for being an american beer that doesnt try to overdue a scottish ale. so many scottish ales made here try to impart so many whiskey notes to the beer that it separates from being enjoyable as a beer onto itself. This one is a nice clear brown color with a pretty sweet caramel taste a bit f roast and malt with touches of bitterness. A real scottish bear made in Cali, well done.

On draft at South Park Tavern in Dayton, OH.  Dark dark brown with an amber tint at the bottom.  Light head if any.  Nice aroma of malts and sweetness.  Great taste, very smooth.  Good solid beer.  Really enjoyed this one.

From tap at Jupiter, Berkeley. Pours dark brown with a small off-white head. Aroma is dark malty, light wooden. Smooth roasted malt, dark caramelish and light breadish. Light bitterness into a malt driven finish. Subdued sweetness.

Whos the big hot bag of air, who doesnt have to comb his hair? Who doesnt bathe and doesnt care, Sanka, Sanka, yay, Sanka! .. Shows alot of alcohol; Its not so much the heat, its the humidity thatll kill you. .. rum and maple flavors ..low medium head .. not that enjoyable .. Dont touch me!
On tap at stone.  Dark copper pour, thin head.  Sweet malt, toffee, plum, peat, and light fruit notes.  Overall not very interesting.
roasty with some coffee flavor with the first sip.  aroma is faint.  some grape flavors in there. liitle scotch notes in the finish.
Brown/copper see through tan head. Sweet malt aroma tastes a little to sweet though. Nice deep aroma too with malt depth in taste and smell.

Location: Draft at Rattle N Hum, 9/13/09


Aroma: Caramel, a bit of scotch, some toffee, and butterscotch

Appearance: Dark caramel brown color, nice head

Flavor: Nice smooth malty and scotch flavor, mild hop bitterness

Palate: Smooth with a nice mouthfeel, minimal harshness from the scotch

Overall Impression:
This is a pretty good scotch, not exceptional, but nice and enjoyable.  Stays true to the style as well.  The type of beer you can definitely enjoy.
Tap at browerij lane. Poured a deep mahogany with a thin head. Nose was sweet and caramel. A bit sweet lots of malt and caramel. Some bitterness. True to the style.

Draft. Pours dark red with a thin head. Toasty malt aroma with toffee and a light fruity sweetness. The flavor is malty, with toasty/earthy/peaty notes, as well as a very light fruity sweetness. Pretty good.
sample: RNH: caramel pour leaving a very thin head.  There is a very strong grassy aftertaste... not such a good thing.  Lots of bitters, high esters, kind of nasty actually.
Draught.  Poured a deep caramel brown with a medium white head.  Strong malty aroma.  Full malty flavour that cuts the bitterness of a salad.  Caramel, raisin and malty notes.  Lasting malt finish.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: Sweet dark Caramel.   Sweet caramel and cocoa aroma.   Some tart notes, forgetable.

A ruby red ale with a thin like moka head. A light sweet butterscotch aroma, nutty and restrained. In mouth, an oily prickly scottish ale with light treacle, apple pulp, and warming alcohol. Medium bodied.  On tap at brewpub, August 16 2009.
Chocolate taste - similar to Bear Republic Peter Brown but a tad better. 8.5

12/06/2007:  Bear Republic Heritage Ale has a really deep amber color with ruby highlights, a dense and lasting dark beige head, intricate lacing, and soft carbonation.  Tons of rich caramel is present in the aroma along with hints of chocolate and fruits.  This beer has a fruity and dark malty flavor.  It is rish and lasting on the palate with some light chocolate and hints of alcohol.  There is a lot of caramelized malts and a smooth, balanced bitterness and coffee ground-like flavor in the finish.  There is a decent amount of residual sweetness in this medium-bodied and smooth beer.  Overall this is a very good beer that drinks like a Scottish 80/- despite the  8.0% ABV!
Pint (draught) at Dilly Deli in Mariemont, Ohio.  Rating #50 for this beer.

Ruby tan pour with an aroma that just doesnt come out of the sample glass very well.  Tastes lovely though with flavors of caramel, toffee, brown sugar, yeast and fruit.  Finishes with caramel, toffee and sourdough toast.  Thick and creamy.  Scotch ales are great, despite not really existing as a style, har har.

Cask at Elysians SBW Firkin-Firkin throwdown (vs. Silver City Fat Woody).  Pours reddish brown with minimal head.  Fruity (strawberry/cherry/orange) and malty with a hint of oatmeal.  Medium bodied with a malty orange finish.  Not a fair fight against the (oak-aged) Fat Woody, which is just a mind-blowing beer and one of my favorites.

Tap at B-Rep.  A girl next to me from Vancouver told me it was bad, but I figured Canadians are not always to be trusted and ordered one anyway.  Copper color with a small cream-colored head.  Aroma of caramel and roasted malt.  Flavor is more of the same - malty - with mild earthy hops.  Somewhat syrupy palate with a medium-full body.
On tap at Pacific Coast Brewing. This dark brown ale poured with a thin beige head and a malty aroma. There is a sweet roasted malt flavor with some smoke and some nice hopping at the finish.
deep copper brown with no head. Caramel and malt aroma and taste with some big banana notes. Stcky sweet finish.

Tap at the Blind Tiger. Oatmeal cookie aroma, chocolate and raisin. Great mild balance to this. Light bitter and smoke flavor, but super-sweet, cloying, way too much so. A big disappointment after the killer aroma. Can hardly drink this at all.
On tap at the Blind Tiger, NYC. Deep amber with a thin lace. Very rich caramel flavour of malt. Sweet as. Little to rich for my liking.

EBF Session 1.  Brown with a ligh tan head.  Aroma of alot of malt- molasses, some toasty, sweet cyrstal malt, and some light earthy hops in the background.  Taste is sweet with molasses, light chocolate, crystal malts.  Full bodied and sweet, probably a bit too sweet overall- but certainly a decent scotch ale. SOme alcohol in the finish.

Tap at BT.  Pours an ok deep amber with a thin diminishing head to nothing.  Aroma is thickly sweet with crystal malt, brown sugar, toffee, light nuts, and slight diacetyl and light tea-like hints.  Flavor is sharp dark crystal malt sweetness, moderate bready and darkly toasted malts, fruity and almost syrupy fruity honey sweet- corn syrupy as it warms.  Meh.

Draft at Rattle n Hum. Dark red with a small head. Aroma is cinnamony spicy hops with a candy apple coating. Flavor is toasty with a bit of a whisky burn. Could be this beers been on for a bit as its got a bit of a butter thing going on. Not as sharp as the last time I had it. Still in all, one of the more agressive Scotch Ales Ive had.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2010 re-rate 9March2010
On tap at Haven Gastro Pub in Orange, CA
Nice & malty up front, with a peaty smokey finish. Very well done. 

-----
On tap at the brewery, I got this as part of a sampler set.
Nice dark red color with a sweet aroma. Lightly carbonated, its malty flavor was nice.

Draft at the brewpub. Dark ruby red color with a slight off-white head. Aroma of darker roasted caramel. Medium  body with mild carbonation. Very dark roast malt flavor with hints of hops. Wee Heavy kind of thing?

Draft at Paradiso.  Amber body with a small white head.  Sweet brown sugar aroma, with some faint notes of nuts and toast.  The flavor is very nice.  Mostly sweet, a faint bit of smokiness toward the finish, and a light bitterness.  Very enjoyable.
interesting scotch ale....very malty and single noted...not a whole lot of complexity but solid all the same

On draft at the Brewpub in Headsburg, CA this came a cloudy burnt amber color wit ha small pub head  Nose of caramel malts and some fruit.  Medium mouthfeel. Flavor is slightly sweet and the finish is the same.  A quite decent beer and easy to drink.

After so many big hoppy beers, this one didn’t really stand out.  Could have also had to do with the fact that I had a nice buzz going.  Rich and red in color, toasty and sweet, but not much bite here.  A beer lost in a sea of hops.

On tap at bear Republic.  They made good use of the  extra alcohol in this beer.  The malty, whiskey finish came through.  I’d prefer something a little more burnt caramel or peaty, but this was pretty good.
Super malty but balanced. dark. mellowed as it warmed. alcohol taste is ever present candi sugar taste present (a negative in my book for this style)
Draft at hop devil grill.  Pours a cloudy brown body with a sweet malty aroma and some dry fruit.   A moderate presence of malt and etoh in the finish.
Draft at Pearly Bakers. Deep red body with thin head. Aroma is hoppy, sweet malt. Flavor is a nice hoppy body, sweet malt and some smoke. Smooth despite the harsh mix of hops.
On tap at Hop Devil Grill - Brown color wiht a malty-sweet aroma.  Flavor is rich and malty with molasses and brown sugar - finishes nice.  Not bad at all, very drinkable.

Tap at Hop Devil - clear brown, purplish beer, with a pillowy, lasting head - very sweet aroma, with dough, brown sugar, light spiciness - taste is medium sweet, with some roasty notes and cocoa - light barleywine character in the form of fruity esters - herbal, bittering hops - a little bit of earthy/peat notes - light cocoa in the finish - pretty nice.

Tap at Hop Devil Grill.  Deep brown beer, thin white head.  Aroma is sweet and treacly with a strong dark caramel character.  Sweet and chewy and a little bit of earthiness coming through.  Lightly spicy and caramelly.  Lightly peaty and chocolatey.  I like this one as well.

Tap @ Bear Republic.  Poured a hazy deep amber color with an off-white head.  Sweet and malty with some dark fruity notes in the flavor  The aroma had a good bit of fruity esters and a moderate sweetness.  Medium bodied with a smooth mouthfeel.  Light earthy finish and some nice warmth.  Not bad.

Draft at the Dilly Deli.  Pours a deep ruby red with a small/medium beige head that fades quickly.  The aroma is moderately sweet malt, alcohol, fruits, and a bit of bread.  The flavor is seet caramel malt, dark fruits, bread, a touch of spice, and toffee.  The alcohol is present but not distracting.  Full bodied, chewy.

Draught at Coles, Buffalo, NY. Pours a deep ruby with an average size tan head. Mild aroma, hard to make out much, I get some toasted malt. Flavour of caramel malt, a bit of smoke, some toastiness and a light bitter finish. Average bodied. Nothing great, simply a decent Scotch Ale, I enjoyed it enough.

On tap at Coles, Buffalo.  Weak nose, maybe some faint fruity malt.  Taste is better, , nice and malty, sweet.  Reddish brown pour with small white head.  Simple Scotch Ale here (alcohol?) but rather drinkable.
On tap @ Coles Buffalo NY. Pours a muddy reddish brown. Peaty, notes of whiskey, slight smoke. Almost tastes dirty if thats a description. Not impressed

Tap @ Pizza Plant.  Brown, ruby highlights.  Nose is cocoa & meladonins, plenty of dusty malt & tobacco.  Flavor is dusty malt, alcohol/whiskey, cocoa, some dark fruitiness.  More whiskey in the finish.
Draft. Dark reddish brown, small head, malty nose. Kind of flat body, malty, sweet, not so great.

On draft.
Pours a dark ruby brown in color.  Theres a head for a few seconds, but then its gone by the time your first sip is done.
Smell is huge malts and some toffee.  Taste is the same with some brown sugar and spice coming through at the end.  Alright tasting and highly sessionable.

Draft at Dilly Deli. Poured clear dark ruby with an average fizzy off-white head that mostly diminished with fair lacing. Moderate toasted ground coffee bean malty aroma.   Medium smooth body. Flavor was a good toasted balanced bittersweet with an average bittersweet finish of moderate duration.
Very malty, bready and toasty nose with a bit of iced tea. Big caramel and chewy biscuit notes hit the palate with a big mouthfeel. Clean and herbal finish.
GABF 2007.  Suprised by the 69% rating on this one.  A nice, malty brew w/ a dry finish.  Very good.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2008 This is a deep, brownish red with a fairly thick and moderately long-lasting light tan head with an orange-red hint.  It has moderate lacing but it is not very long-lasting.  It smells of rich grain, caramel and a hint of nuts.  The taste is fairly full and well-rounded, with a sweet, malty caramel element, a hint of nut, and definite, but not overpowering bitterness, making it quite balanced.  It has just a faint  yeasty element which is fine here but if any stronger  would certainly detract.  As it is, it blends well with the caramel element and in the finish fades into a nice, faint chocolate element. It has a moderately thick, oily palate.  For a Scotch Ale/Wee Heavy, this one goes unusually well with food.

Sampled at the 5th Annual Boulder Strong Ale Fest. Beer is clear, medium brown with a small, light brown, frothy, mostly and quickly diminishing head.

The aroma is malty with a light note of toasted grain; Hoppy with a light note of resin/pine; Yeasty with a light note of basement; Trace note of oak.

The flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter with a long, moderately bittersweet finish.

The body is medium, the texture is watery and the carbonation is lively.

On tap @ 5th Annual Boulder Strong Ale Fest poured a clear reddish brown with a small lasting amber head. Aromas of carmel, cocoa, brown sugar and a hint of smoke. Palate was medium bodied and dry. Flavors of maltiness, tobacco and light toffee with a dry bittersweet finish.

Draft. Ruby/mahogony beer with an off-white head. Sweet caramel malt aroma. Caramel malt flavor with some earthiness. Lingering caramel and earth. Fuller bodied. Pretty good scotch ale thats clean and straight forward - lots of carmelized malt.

Deep mahogany with a soapy, tan head. Odd floral character to nose atop a rye base with a mild, sweet grapey-vinousness. Flavor finds predominant alcohol over rye & roasts. Thin flavored and wholly unimpressive.
<font size=-4>On cask at <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/events-detail.asp?eve of the Living Ales III, Goose Island Wrigleyville 03/03/07</font>
cask at NotLA.  i actually liked it alot.  i definitely didnt think it was a scotch ale.  a bit hoppy aroma and a nice malt backbone for taste.  red in color and balanced all around.

A little surprized to see this is a Scotch Ale, usually big & bold malty drinks.  This was fairly watery without a lot of flavor to it.  It poured a deep reddish brown with a slender head and had only a faint, toasted malt aroma.  Some fruit is added to the flavor to perk it up a bit, but over all it disappoints.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/events-detail.asp?eve of the Living Ales III, Goose Island - Wrigleyville, Chicago, IL, 3/3/2007.<font size=-1>
on cask at the Night of the Living Ales 07. strange watery, weak malt, low hop profile. not so good.

Draught at Catos Ale House in Oakland, CA. Fresh, fruity aroma that is not overly hoppy. Reddish, murky body with no head and no lace. I ordered this brew at 2pm on a Saturday. The place was pretty dead. I am wondering if it had been sitting in the lines, explaining why it was somewhat flat. Nevertheless, nice hops, which is a little off-style for a Scotch ale. Very flavorful. Session quality. Very solid and enjoyable.
malty aroma with a hint of roastiness, transparent dark red, surprisingly light bodied, tons of caramely malt flavors and a hint of smokiness
Tap @ brewpub.  Red to brown color.  Aroma has a lot of malts and is a little sweet.  Flavor has smoke or campfire flavors with malts and some alcohol.
On tap, GABF 02:  Sweet malt aroma, medium red/orange color with no head.  Virtually flat.  Light sweet ending.  I would have enjoyed this if it had more carbonation.

Re-Rate : Better with effervescence - light and medium heavy creamy foam, deep amber color, clear, like Red Rocket but softer maltier and less peat but lacking balance. There must be an amazing brew in between Red Rocket and this beer though these poles are also extraordinary in their own rites.  Re-Rate of: Cask 2002: Slightly bready, almost no aroma. This one came in completely flat and gained a few bubbles after a couple days in a half ferkin. Slightly reddish. Slightly sweet.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2011 Draft, 2/15/11.  Large beige head, copper body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, caramel, raisin/cherry.  Taste is moderately sweet, caramel, cherry/raisin.  Medium body, low carbonation, light stickiness.  7/3/7/3/14

Tasting Notes from Fall 2000:  Pleasant bitterness, generally true to style. 5/4/7/3/13
